STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
August 23, 2022
Shantheis Moody
Bethany Christian Services Inc-Grand Rapids
901 Eastern Avenue, NE
Grand Rapids, MI 49501-0294
RE: License #: CB410200976
Bethany Christian Services Inc-Grand Rapids
901 Eastern Avenue, NE
Grand Rapids, MI 49501-0294
Dear Mr. Moody:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
August 19, 2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It
should be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of
the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of
this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
(231) 342-3721
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB410200976
Licensee Name: Bethany Christian Services Inc
Licensee Address: 901 Eastern Avenue NE
Grand Rapids, MI 49503
Licensee Telephone #: (616) 224-7610
Administrator/Licensee Designee: George Tyndall, Designee
Name of Facility: Bethany Christian Services Inc-Grand Rapids
Facility Address: 901 Eastern Avenue, NE
Grand Rapids, MI 49501-0294
Facility Telephone #: (616) 459-6273

CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE
SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME
EVALUATE APPLICANTS FOR ADOPTION

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records
(3) The personnel record shall contain:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member’s performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months after the
staff member assumes his or her current responsibilities. After
the initial evaluation, a written evaluation shall be conducted each
year.
One of twelve personnel files reviewed did not contain written evaluations as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISTED
9/21/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 11/5/2021
R 400.12306 Application request
(4) An agency shall document that the licensee has been given
an application for renewal of the license not less than 60 days
before the expiration date of the license.
Three of eight foster home files reviewed did not provide the licensee an application
for renewal at least 60 days prior to the expiration of the license.
File one: License expired 2/6/2022 and renewal application sent on 1/13/2022
File two: License expired 11/2/2021 and renewal application sent on 9/21/2021
File three: License expired 3/22/2022 and renewal application sent on 1/25/2022
R 400.12312 Foster parent training
(4) At least 1 adult member of the household shall have training
in and maintain a current certification in first aid from the
American Heart Association or the American Red Cross or other
institution approved by the department.
One of eight foster home files reviewed did not have current certification in first aid as
required.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15 calendar
days before the expiration date of the foster home license.
4

Four of eight open foster home files reviewed did not have documentation the
licensing recommendation was made to the department at least 15 calendar days
before the expiration date of the foster home license.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) Agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at a minimum,
include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated:
(II) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical examination
shall be completed within 30 calendar days after placement.
Two of eight open foster care files reviewed did not have an initial medical
examination completed within 30 calendar days after placement as required.
File one: Initial medical not timely, youth was removed on 8/12/2021 and medical was
10/18/2021.
File two: Initial medical was not completed within 30 days of removal. Child was
removed 2/10/2022 and initial medical was 3/18/2022.
R 400.12417 Foster parent information
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child:
(a) Child's name.
(b) Child's date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child's health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating to the
care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or replacement of the
child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster parent to
provide a stable, safe, and healthy environment for the foster
child and the foster family, including information about siblings
who do not reside in the foster home.
4 of 8 open foster care case files reviewed did not contain documentation that all
information required within subsection a-h of this rule was provided to the caregivers
within the timeframes outlined within the rule.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at least
once every 90 calendar days.
5

One of eight foster care files reviewed did not have the Updated Service Plan
completed timely.
File one: USP not completed timely; report due 7/19/2022 and was submitted on
7/20/2022.
R 400.12422 Foster care record
(8) The record shall contain all of the following information:
(g) A photograph taken at least annually.
Two of eight open foster care files reviewed did not have a photograph of the youth as
required.
File one: There is not a picture uploaded of child at the time of placement.
File two: Picture was not updated annually. Date of picture is 12/4/2020.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth
and the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed
and updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
Two of three open independent living files reviewed did not contain documentation the
independent living contract was updated and provided to the youth at least every 90
calendar days as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/21/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 11/5/2021
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the
following:
ISEP 6.16 Supervisory oversight
Supervisors shall meet at least monthly with each assigned
worker to review the status and progress of each case on the
worker’s caseload.
One of eight open foster care files reviewed did have documented monthly
supervision with staff as required.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
6

FOM 722-06H Quality visits
Quality visits between the caseworker and child have been found
to produce positive outcomes for children in foster care. A quality
visit is defined as one in which the caseworker:
 Can meet with each child individually, without the presence of
other individuals, to give the child an opportunity to ask
questions as well as discuss the current placement.
 Views the child's bedroom and sleeping arrangements.
 Verifies safe sleep environments and practices for infants
under 12 months.
 Assesses each child’s educational, medical, dental, mental
health and other needs and takes appropriate action or offers
services in response to the identified needs of each child.
 Shows interest in the child to build and establish rapport.
 Shares and explains the case plan, including the plan for
parenting time, visits with siblings and other relatives, and the
child's permanency plan, in a developmentally appropriate
way while allowing the child to ask questions and express
viewpoints.
One of eight foster care files reviewed did not contain documentation of a quality visit.
File one: 1/20/2022 home visit does not document a quality visit was conducted.
FOM 722-08 Supervisor approval
The supervisor must approve all case service plans within 14
days of the end of the report period.
Five of eight foster care files and two of three independent living files reviewed did not
have supervisory approval of the case service plan within 14 days as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/25/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 10/1/2020
9/21/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 11/5/2021
7

FOM 722-08C Foster Care-Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service
Agreement
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate, including
those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker, supervisor,
foster parent, caregiver, any youth aged 14 and older and in the
case of placement agency foster care cases, the local DHS office
designee.
8

Seven of eight foster care files and three of three independent living files reviewed did
not contain all of the required signatures on the parent agency treatment plan (PATP).
File one: 12/1/2021 PATP: relative signature not timely (6/30/2022), mother and youth
not dated; 2/24/2022 PATP: relative signature not timely (6/30/2022); 5/17/2022
PATP: relative signature not timely (6/30/2022), youth signature not uploaded for
5/17/2022 PATP
File two: 10/18/2021 PATP: youth signature not uploaded; 1/10/2022 PATP: youth
signature not timely (3/16/2022), 4/7/2022 PATP: youth signature not timely
(7/27/2022), 6/23/2022 PATP: youth signature not timely (7/27/2022), father signature
not obtained or documented why it could not be obtained
File three:12/21/2021 PATP: does not have FP or mother signature; 3/1/2022 PATP:
FP signature not obtained timely (4/5/2022), mother signature not obtained; 4/5/2022
PATP: mother signature not obtained; 5/27/2022 PATP: FP signature not obtained
timely (7/21/2022), mother and father signature not obtained
File four: 3/9/2022 PATP does not have mother or father signature, relative signature
not obtained timely (5/2/2022); 6/2/2022 PATP does not have mother signature, father
signature not obtained timely (7/25/2022), relative signature is signed but not dated
File five: 11/23/2021 PATP does not have FP signature, father's signature not
obtained timely (5/4/2022), 2/18/2022 PATP: relative signature not obtained timely
(4/11/2022), dad signature not obtained timely (5/4/2022-there is a SWC on 4/4
indicating he refused to sign but it would not have been timely), 5/10/2022 PATP:
relative signature not obtained, father’s signature not obtained timely (8/13/2022).
File six: 12/16/2021 PATP: father's signature not timely (1/26/2022), 3/7/2022 PATP:
father's signature not timely (4/21/2022), 5/26/2022 PATP: mother refusal not timely
(7/11/2022)
File seven: 11/23/2021 PATP: does not have youth signature; 2/18/2022 PATP:
mother signature not timely (5/23/2022), does not have youth signature; 5/16/2022
PATP: does not have youth signature
File eight: 2/3/2022 PATP: youth signature not obtained timely (3/18/2022), 5/3/2022
PATP: youth signature not obtained timely (6/7/2022)
File nine: 10/11/2021, 1/5/2022, 4/4/2022, and 6/21/2022 PATP's do not have youth
signature
File ten: Youth signature obtained for 11/2/2021 PATP, 1/21/2022 PATP, 4/12/2022
and 6/22/2022 PATP but none are dated
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/25/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 10/1/2020
9/21/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 11/5/2021
9

FOM 722-08E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Summary
The caseworker must complete the DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile
Justice Action Summary and upload to MISACWIS within the
timeframe required for the specified action/change.
Two of eight foster care files reviewed did not have the DHS-69 Action Summary
forms completed for placement changes as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/21/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 11/5/2021 (cited under FOM 722-08C)
FOM 722-06H Contact with parent or guardian when child is placed out-of-
home
First Month after Initial Out-of-Home Placement
The primary foster care caseworker must have at least two face-
to-face contacts with the legal parent or guardian, with at least
one contact occurring at the parent or guardian's home or living
environment, during the first month following initial out-of-home
placement.
Subsequent Calendar Months
The primary foster care caseworker must have face-to-face
contact with the legal parent or guardian at least once per
calendar month. At least one contact each quarter must occur in
the parent’s residence.
One of eight foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the foster care
caseworker had the required face-to-face contact with the legal parent or guardian in
their home or living environment as required.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
Case Plan Development/Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
10

Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption
At least three business days prior to a planned change of
placement or no later than three business days after an
unplanned placement change.
Planned and unplanned placement changes include reunification,
placement in a residential setting, step-down from a residential or
hospital setting, return from AWOLP, or request for change in
foster home/relative placements.
Five of eight foster care files and two of three independent living files reviewed did not
have FTM’s completed as required.
File one: There is no corresponding FTM for 5/17/2022 USP.
File two: There is no corresponding FTM for 1/10/2022 USP, 4/7/2022 USP,
6/23/2022 USP and 10/14/2021, 4/4/2022, 5/31/2022 placement changes.
File three: There is no corresponding FTM for 3/1/2022 USP.
File four: There is no corresponding FTM for 2/18/2022 and 5/10/2022 USP.
File five: There is no corresponding FTM for 11/23/2021 USP and 2/18/2022 USP.
File six: There is no corresponding FTM for 11/24/2021 USP and 2/7/2022 USP.
File seven: There is no corresponding FTM for 4/12/2022 USP.
FOM 722-06B FTM Documentation
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in MiSACWIS
using the FTM hyperlink within seven business days of the FTM.
Six of eight foster care files and three of three independent living files reviewed
contained FTM’s without the DHS 1105 or the DHS 1105 was not uploaded within
seven business days.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/25/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 10/1/2020
9/21/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 11/5/2021
FOM 723 Educational services
Individualized Education Plan (IEP)
11

All educational information and related tasks, activities, and
contacts must be documented within the social work contacts,
case service plans, placement, and the education section of
MiSACWIS.
One of eight foster care files reviewed did not have the education section of
MISACWIS completed to reflect the youth’s IEP.
FOM 722-06H Contact with child in out-of-home placement
First Month after Initial Out-of-Home Placement
 The caseworker must have at least two face-to-face contacts
per month with each child in the first two months following
an initial placement or a placement change.
 The first face-to-face contact must take place within five
business days of the date of removal or placement change.
 At least one contact each month must take place in the
child’s placement setting.
 Each required contact must include a private meeting
between the child and the caseworker; see Private Meeting
in this item.
One of eight foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the foster care
caseworker had the required face-to-face contact with the child during the first two
months following the initial placement.
FOM 801-03 Medical passports
An updated medical passport is provided to:
 Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary court
ward.
Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
At reunification. Subsequent medical passports are not
required after reunification.
 The child’s foster care provider:
At or prior to each placement.
Quarterly.
12

 All medical and mental health professionals to whom the child
is newly referred to and accepted for treatment and/or
services prior to or at the first scheduled appointment while
the foster care case is open, regardless of placement.
Subsequent medical passports are not required.
 Older youth/young adults:
Upon initial independent living placement (youth age 16
and over).
Upon exiting the foster care system (young adults age
18 and older).
Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC) youth/young
adult:
Within two weeks of re-entry into voluntary foster care.
Upon exiting voluntary foster care.
Five of eight open foster care files reviewed did not have medical passports and
required signatures.
File one: Initial medical passport not timely, youth was removed on 8/12/2021 and
medical passport was completed 10/18/2021.
File two: There were no medical passports from 2/3/2021-3/16/2022.
File three: Initial medical passport not timely, youth was removed on 11/3/2021 and
medical passport was completed 12/23/2021.
File four: Initial medical was not timely. Child was removed 2/10/2022 and initial
medical passport was completed 3/18/2022.
File five: There are no medical passports uploaded.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/25/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 10/1/2020
9/21/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 11/5/2021
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 PATP’s must be dated.
 Document on PATP signature line if report was mailed, emailed, or client
refused to sign.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
13

The facility did not request consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted four acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
SIR 2022C0212002 was initiated on 11/22/2021 due to allegations the agency did
not complete required monthly contact between siblings. The investigation
determined a violation of R 400.12421 visitation and parenting time. A CAP was
approved on 1/7/2022 and was completed.
SIR 2022C0212006 was initiated on 1/26/2022 due to allegations the agency
conducted two special evaluations in which the findings and recommendations did
not accurately reflect the information contained in the report. The investigation
determined a violation of R 400.12327 special evaluation. A CAP was approved on
4/11/2022 and continues to be implemented at this time.
SIR 2022C0112007 was initiated on 2/15/2022 due to allegations the agency did not
provide reasonable efforts to reunify a family. The investigations determined a
violation of FOM 722-06 reasonable efforts. A CAP was approved on 5/4/2022 and
continues to be implemented at this time.
The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan in response to the
interim inspection completed on 9/21/2021 with a corrective action plan approved on
11/5/2021. During the review the agency had eleven violations. Seven citations were
noted as repeat violations in the current inspection. During this period under review
the agency expressed the impact of adjusting to a hybrid work schedule and high
needs cases had on overall compliance. In addition, the agency noted that staff
turnover and retention impacted overall compliance.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator assessment reported the agency’s difficulty in meeting
requirements during this review period. The Chief Administrator stated the previous
year CAP was somewhat effective due to processes being put in place that the
agency feels will reduce the number of citations. The Chief Administrator
assessment reported ongoing challenges related to staff turnover and hiring a large
number of new staff impacted overall compliance with licensing rules and policy.
The Chief Administrator indicated ongoing training and support for staff and
supervisors has been a focus of the agency. Additional oversight, utilization of
Quality Assurance Manager and implementation of checklists have had a positive
impact. The Chief Administrator expressed confidence that several areas will
improve over the next review period.
14

Interviews
Interviews were conducted with four staff via telephone. Staff acknowledged this
year has been somewhat difficult due to a large number of newer staff. However,
they feel the agency is doing all they can to adjust and provide support and
anticipate improvement over the next review period. Staff reported supervision is
available when needed and they reported no areas of need.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
___________8/19/2022__________________________
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
August 23, 2022
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
